questions.question: 767A patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the second postoperative dayfollowing a cholecystectomy. Evaluation reveals a collection in the subhepatic space. A bileleak was suspected. Which of the following is the best investigation for this patient?
questions.explanation: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the best investigation in a patientsuspected of post-cholecystectomy biliary leaks.Patients with post-cholecystectomy biliary leak usually present with fever, jaundice andabdominal pain. questions.question: Five days following a common bile duct injury resulting in a leak, a patient presents withfever and abdominal pain. What would be the next step in management?
questions.explanation: In the case of a common bile duct injury with a leak and a patient presenting with signs oflocalized peritonitis, the next step of management is an ultrasound-guided aspiration. This willbe followed by ERCP and stenting.Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the most common cause of bile duct injury. Major biliary leakageis usually seen 2 to 10 days after cholecystectomy. Affected patients typically present with:• Fever• Abdominal pain• Bilious ascites• Mild jaundice•⚫ Leukocytosis• Elevations in the serum levels of ALP and GGT.Management of bile duct injury:If the injury is identified during surgery:•Partial injury to the bile duct (<3mm) - repair the injury•Complete transection without loss of segment - anastomose over T-tube• Complete transection with loss of segment - close distal end and carry out Roux-en-Yhepaticoduodenostomy/jejunostomyIf the leak is suspected postoperatively:Transabdominal ultrasonography is initially performed to assess the leak..• If the patient presents within 48 hours - Re-explore and repair• If the patient presents after 48 hours - USG-guided aspiration or pigtail catheter insertion.776This is followed by ERCP and stenting.Management of bile duct injuriesAssess the type of injuryto thePartial injurybile duct (<3mm)Repairthe injuryComplete transectionwithout lossof a segmentComplete transectionwith lossof segmentAnastomoseover T-tubeIf the injury is identifiedduring the surgeryClose distal end andcarry out Roux-en-Yhepatico duodenostomyjejunostomyDo transabdominal USG to assess the leakIf the patient presentswithin 48 hoursRe-explorationand repairIf the patient presentsafter 48 hoursUSG guided aspiration orpigtail catheter insertionERCP and stentingIf the biliary leak issuspected postoperativelyMARROW

questions.question: Where does biliary stricture most commonly occur after laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
questions.explanation: Biliary stricture after laparoscopic cholecystectomy usually occurs in the common hepaticduct, distal to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts.After open cholecystectomy, biliary strictures are more common in the common bile duct.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about hemobilia?

options.A: It is associated with Quincke's triad
options.B: Tumors are the most common cause of bleeding
options.D: Arterial angiography is the diagnostic procedure of choice

questions.explanation: The most common cause of hemobilia is iatrogenic trauma.Hemobilia is defined as bleeding into the biliary tree from abnormal communication between ablood vessel and bile duct.Causes of hemobilia include:• Traumatic or operative injury to the liver or bile ducts• Intraductal rupture of a hepatic abscess or aneurysm of the hepatic artery• Biliary or hepatic tumor hemorrhage• Mechanical complications of choledocholithiasis or hepatobiliary parasitism.• Diagnostic procedures, such as liver biopsy, percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC),and transhepatic biliary drainage catheter placement• Vascular disordersPatients often present with a classic triad (Quincke's triad/Sandblom triad) of:•Biliary pain777• Obstructive jaundice• Melena or occult blood in the stoolsInvestigation of choice: Arterial angiography (CT angiography) is the diagnostic procedure ofchoice.Management:Minor hemobilia can be managed conservatively.Major hemobilia: Transarterial embolization is indicated for major hemobilia requiring bloodtransfusion. Ligation of the bleeding vessel may also be required.

questions.question: How will you confirm the diagnosis in a patient suspected to have bilhemia?
questions.explanation: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the best investigation for thediagnosis of bilhemia.Bilhemia is a condition in which bile flows into the bloodstream through the hepatic veins orportal vein branches. This flow occurs due to a high intrabiliary pressure, exceeding that of thevenous system.The cause can be the erosion of gallstones into the portal vein, or accidental/iatrogenic trauma.This condition can be fatal secondary to the embolization of large amounts of bile into the lungs.Usually, bile flow is low, and the fistulas close spontaneously.Its clinical features include:• Rapidly progressive jaundice• Marked direct hyperbilirubinemia, without elevation of the hepatocellular enzyme levels.•Septicemia.Diagnosis of bilhemia is best made by ERCP.Treatment is directed at reducing the intrabiliary pressure through stent placement orsphincterotomy. Endovascular embolization can also be done.

questions.question: Cholangiohepatitis is associated with which of the following parasites?
questions.explanation: Cholangiohepatitis or recurrent pyogenic cholangitis is associated with biliary parasites such as: Clonorchis sinensis, Opisthorchis viverrini, and Ascaris lumbricoides. It is caused by bacterial contamination of the biliary tree. Some commonly implicated organisms are Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species, Bacteroides species, or Enterococcus faecalis. Cholangiohepatitis is a pre-malignant condition and can result in cholangiocarcinoma. Schistosoma haematobium primarily causes genitourinary schistosomiasis. Paragonimus westermani (oriental lung fluke) causes a pulmonary syndrome characterized by cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis.

Cholangiocarcinomas are encountered in three anatomic regions:• Intrahepatic.•• Hilar (65%) - also known as Klatskin tumoursPeripheral (30%)The sclerosing variant of cholangiocarcinoma is the most common and most difficult to treat. questions.question: What is the most common type of choledochal cyst?
questions.explanation: Type I is the most common type of choledochal cyst (75%).Choledochal cysts are congenital dilations of the intra- and/or extra-hepatic biliary system.

questions.question: In which of the following conditions will you perform the Kasai procedure?
questions.explanation: Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for extrahepatic biliary atresia. Inthe Kasai procedure, the occluded extrahepatic bile ducts are excised and a jejunal Roux loop isanastomosed to the hepatic hilum.Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) is defined as a partial or total absence of permeable bile ductbetween porta hepatis and the duodenum. It is due to inflammatory fibrosis of the biliary tree. Itleads to obstruction to bile flow thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into thecirculation.Associated anomalies include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and apreduodenal portal vein.HIDA scan is the investigation of choice for EHBA. Intraoperative cholangiogram is the goldstandard for diagnosis.Infants with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after Kasai's procedure,require liver transplantation within the first year of life.
